captions.text:
Hey, Vsauce, Michael here, and today we're
going to discuss Deja vu. What is it, and

why does it occur? You know, those moments
where the current situation feels like it's

happened before? You're certain it has, but
you don't know when, or how it became so familiar.

It's difficult to scientifically study Deja
vu because there's no reliable way to cause
it to happen in people's heads in a laboratory.

But here's what we do know: humans don't seem
to experience Deja vu until they're at least

8 or 9 years old. It's most frequent in your
teens and twenties, and then tapers off as

you get older. So, it might have something
to do with brain development. In fact, we

should probably go get ourselves a brain.
That was easy. Now, like a stomach ache, Deja

vu may be a symptom with many possible causes.
A lot of the popular theories about what causes

it involve a disconnect that may be occurring
between the deep structures of the brain that

process our experiences unconsciously, and
the parts of the brain that are conscious

about what they experience, process it, and
then tell us what we're seeing.

For the sake of simplicity, let's begin with
the visual system. Now, the brain sits in

your head like this, and your eyeballs are
over here seeing things, sending that signal

to the back of the brain, the Occipital lobe,
where visual cortex is. That's where the image

is processed and we become aware of what we're
seeing. But visual cortex isn't the first

stop that information makes. Instead, we know
that it stops in lots of other places. For

instance, the amygdala, where it may be processed
at an involuntary emotional level, and this

fun little part right here, #31, the tectum.
It's involved in preliminary visual processing
and helps control eye movements.

Now, that fact is incredibly important because
what it means is that people with blindness

cause by brain damage to the visual cortex
cannot see anything. They don't report seeing

or recognizing anything; however, the other
preliminary parts of the brain that get that

message are still healthy, and so, despite
being legally blind, these people exhibit
what is known as blindsight.

They can defy all odds and avoid an obstacle
course on the ground. They can also be presented

faces showing joy, or anxiety and fear, and
feel, without knowing why, at all, on Earth they feel
that way, a similar emotion.

So, a lot is going on when we look at things,
and if those preliminary structures in the

vision system allow certain blind people to
be oddly and unconsciously aware of what they're

looking at, we may have the ingredients we
need for this disconnect.

Think of it this way: If I experience event
A, and then B, and then C, and the inner parts

of my brain commit it to memory and generate
an emotional response, but then, a fraction

of a second later, out-of-sync, my visual
cortex finally gets around to telling me,

the conscious aware part of my brain, what
I'm seeing. It will say "Ok guys, we're looking

at A, and then B, and then..." and then the
brain says "Whoa, whoa, whoa, wait, wait,

and then C, right? That's already happened
I thought?..." and that may be Deja vu.

But what could call these processes dealing
with the same information to get temporarily

out-of-sync like that? Well, it's probably
a neurological abnormality, possibly an epileptic

episode where neurons all fire in sync. We
also know that patients who experience chronic

and persistent Deja vu tend to have brain
damage in the temporal lobes of their brain-
these lobes on either side.

Well that sounds kinda bad, right? I mean, when I
experience Deja vu should I run to the doctor

right away? Well, not at all. In fact, minor
epileptic events are quite common. You've

probably experienced a similar phenomenon
known as a Hypnogogic Jerk. That's a fancy

name for what occurs when you're about to
fall asleep and then all of the sudden you

feel like you're falling, or that you tripped,
and your body jolts itself awake.

What's going on there is that as you fall
asleep your muscles relax, and some part of

your brain that's still awake notices that,
and feels like you're no longer supported-

you must be falling- and it sends out a huge
signal that causes all of your muscles to
twitch, waking you up.

Oh, and Deja vu is not the only "vu" out there.
There's also something known as Presque vu,

or "tip of the tongue," and this is what happens
when you're familiar with something, you know

you know it, but, for the life of you, at that
moment, you cannot recall it. It's like "what's

that actor's name from that movie? I've seen
it 18 times, how can I not remember it?? Wow."

One explanation of how that happens is that
other words similar to the target word are

being remembered, and to help you out your
brain is actively blocking other stuff around

it, including the word you're actually looking
for. Now, this explanation is really nice

cause it might actually explain why Presque
vu has a shared, or social aspect. Even a

bunch of people in a group, all with special
brains, if they're given the same "blocking

words" that are related, no one in the group
can come up with the name until the subject

is changed and those words are no longer blocked,
and then all the sudden someone goes "Oh,

Gary Sinise, that's who it was. Yup, there
you go."

Ok, finally, Jamais vu. This is when something
that you know, something that you're familiar

with, all the sudden seems brand new and bizarre.
Schizophrenic patients will sometimes see

people they know and insist that it's not
the person the know. Instead, it's an imposter.

But all of us have probably experienced Jamais
vu to a certain extent, for instance, when

you repeat a word over, and over, and over,
and over again, the word starts to lose its

meaning and you start to think "What? How
is this even a word? It's so weird!" Well,

scientists believe that happens because continuing
to excite the neurons responsible for that

word causes them to become inhibited, and
further use is less intense.

It is just crazy to think that there is so
much out there in the world, in the universe,

that we don't know, that we don't understand,
that we haven't yet discovered. But, yet,

that very feeling of familiarity for what
we do know can't always be trusted. About

the only constant seems to be: As always,
thanks for watching.

comments.text:
that was interesting..i've had alot of dreams really happened.thoughts of 
something happening n within minutes,next day,month or even a year 
later..it really happened exactly the same.here's just one example;it was 
1980 something.it was around 11pm or so.everyone else was in bed.i was 
watching solid gold..when ricky nelson came on n while he was singing with 
guitar..i thought..he's sure been around a long time n he seems like a nice 
man.then a frightening feeling came rushing over me,which i had no control 
of..just then,my mind saw a flash of a plane..i thought..omg,please don't 
let anything bad happen.after it was over i went to bed.next morning,my 
aunt came in n woke up..saying ricky nelson was killed in a plane crash 
this morning..i felt very sad about it..there being no way to even warn 
him.it's a true story.i have no reason to make it up.how could i have known 
the night before?when i have those types of thoughts or dreams,it usually 
cant be stopped,as if it's already done.very strange.i dont like putting 
stuff out here cuz it sounds crazy.﻿

I dream things, like once i dreamed that someone had said something (what 
they said, i do not remember) and then who knows how long later they said 
something, i recognized it, and i felt myself trying to do what i was... 
Supposed to do? next. it always confuses me, cuz soon i run out of script, 
or i don't do something exactly right, or they had a different reaction 
than what was supposed to happen. The odd thing is, I have seen people I 
recognized, and had talked to, although i had never seen them before. I 
know their names and other random things that i know they havent told me. 
It sometimes happens that i'll know exactly what will happen five minutes 
before it happens, although there was nothing to clue me in on that event. 
Is that normal? Mostly it comes in dream form, and i know this sounds 
weird, but i think people actually sort of do have superpowers. 
small powers, though, not flying (i don't think)
Seeing the future
Five-second super-strength
camouflage (i mean like being so still or something that no one notices ya)
mind reading / telepathy (it seriously works!!!)
and a few more. but really, who says that superpowers are fake?﻿

comments.text:
I've only experienced hypnogogic jerks after sleeping for about 5 hours, it 
happens in most of my nightmares and that's how I wake up from them. When 
my nightmares actually scare me enough I try to jump off of a high place 
and my body experiences a hypnogogic jerk. 
This may be boring in a second so let me tell you this, I have photographic 
memory, meaning I remember things very VERY vividly. Where you remember 
everything is a different thing.
These are the times I've experienced hypnogogic jerks.
(This May get boring now)

1. When I was somewhere from 6-10 I had a dream where was dangling off the 
side of a building. I was screaming for my mom and then I noticed she 
couldn't hear me, she was nowhere near me. I let go and fell and 
milliseconds before I hit the ground I wake up and my legs fly up (it's 
weird)
2 When I was from 7-9 I had a dream that I was in a post-apocalyptic 
version of my house. I heard footsteps and the front door opening so I had 
to decide; hide behind the door or the dresser. Before I could hide, a 
version of the chainsaw majini from resident evil 5 comes into my room and 
picks me up by my ankle and flings me through the window. Yet again, I wake 
up just before I land.

3. Sometime between 5-10. I had a dream where I was in some sort of temple 
with tons of door frames. Every time I tried to go through one, a black 
(not racist, it was like a cartoony black, like a monster's) hand would 
come from the side of the door. After a while if doing this, I got to the 
top of the temple. There was one final door and I tried to go through it 
but I slipped with my feet going backwards (I was going to faceplant) The 
black hand pushed me off if the roof of the temple and I fell about 5 
stories to the ground, I wake up.


And people tell me I'm stupid because I'm scared of heights ﻿

comments.text:
My opinion is that Deja Vu could be as well caused by the things we IMAGINE 
... you know, you're about to have a date and you never had it before with 
that person, you don't know that person much and you imagine that date to 
be smooth, both of you laughing and having fun, enjoying it - just simply 
you imagine it to be perfect. Then youz sometimes imagine how a job 
interview could be happening, other times you plan in your had which routes 
to take on a trip, or there is times when you plan what you're going to 
write, draw, say, etc.... so i think that sometimes you might imagine an 
event, happening on a place that you have never been before or barely know, 
with people that you have never talked to before and so on and you imagine 
how it all could happen, and it is perhaps a thing / event that might 
happen in the future ... you think about it, then perhaps let it go or just 
forget it ... yet it still might be in your memory ... and sometimes it 
just might so happen that it happens just how you have imagined it, or 
pretty much how you have imagined it and then you're like "oh, i've already 
been here before, i've already lived this moment!" ... and or when it comes 
to dreams- what i have read or heard so far is that in dreams we sometimes 
"deal" with things that might come up and so even in dreams we might dream 
about upcoming events, then it happens - i guess you get the idea.﻿

comments.author: f_3run0_r

comments.text:
Youre wrong. You are one hundred and fifty percent wrong. Ive gotten Deja 
Vu mutiple times and everytime i got it, i recognized that it was something 
i had experienced in another lifetime. It wasnt just a feeling of 
familiarity, it was an experience that was so precise so crystal clear, i 
knew it was more than my mind playing tricks on me. It was something 
greater... An external memory... Let me explain; An external memory is 
something that you experience in a life cycle that your mind has saved as a 
check point or as a message to ones own self, that you will recognize in 
the same life experience but in another moment in time. Bringing you to an 
alternate reality and sense of familiarity. To understand this, you have to 
first understand time and more importantly, life. Time has no beginning or 
end. "How is this relative to Deja Vu?" Its relative because the mind and 
the universe are one, traveling from experience to experience. Deja Vu is 
like forseeing the future, except the future doesnt exist because time 
doesnt actually exist. In reality, it just repeats. Its possible that 
through this infinite space and time, our lives repeat an infinite amount 
of times, and at any given moment your mind takes a snap shot of certain 
moments in a life cycle. This is what Deja Vu is. It has nothing to do with 
epilepsy.. Or schizophrenia... Or any other brain disorder. Its also 
possible that Deja Vu and destiny coexist. "How is this possible? And why?" 
You might ask... Well In external form the mind is in a state of 
perfection. Meaning we are in a state of perfect being. We know no greed, 
no pain, no fear, no emotions, no urges or sensations of the senses we gain 
from having a physical form. Because we arent in a physical form we are 
nothing but intelligence. Destiny would be described as our spiritual 
beings choosing a forseen path. Almost like a challenge of will power. We 
are all destined to be great. So we choose a predetermined path. But as we 
journey through a life experience in physical form we stray from our 
destined course. Maybe Deja Vu is a message to our physical being from our 
spiritual being, a message of/for good or bad. See science can only explain 
so much. And its often innaccurate, and denotes the truth, persuading 
others to believe something false. When in fact our minds are telling us 
the truth. The mind is a powerfull thing. You cant always rely on 
scientific explainations. 

For example, the "Big Bang Theory". Its simply just a theory. It denotes a 
universal intelligence or a higher power, stating that life is random. But 
if life began from cosmic gases, then ill simply ask, what created those 
gases? And if something created those gases, then again, ill ask, what 
created that?? same thing can be asked about "god". Who or what created 
god? And if so, what created that?? Theres always a new question to arise 
with every answer. The questions become infinite, as well as the answers 
do, until you reach the easiest explaination... Nothing. In the beginning 
there was nothing. Nothing but black, empty, darkness. But if life and all 
things began from nothing, than truly nothing is everything, because all 
things derived from nothing. This is how we know time is actually infinite, 
and if time is infinite than it is also irrelevant. Why? Because if time is 
infinite, life is infinite as well, and there is nothing to fear. The truth 
is life has no beginning or end. Yes our lives do...but that is the purpose 
of physicality. What we are experiencing in this moment is all we know. Its 
all we wanted to know, for a brief moment of infinity. This is the purpose 
of life, to experience. What is beyond this we only imagine. 

﻿
comments.author: Clinton T

comments.text:
I actually remember, when I was about 6 or 7, telling my aunt about an 
experience I 'had' even though it didn't happen yet. About 8 years later, I 
found myself in that situation. That's usually what I think of as Deja Vu. 
At least the type I sometimes get.﻿
comments.author: FourthDimensionPyro

O MY GOD now i finally know what im experiencing. ugh DEJA VUUUU and tip of

comments.author: Maggie Mertsock

comments.text: I have some serious déjà vú problems.﻿
comments.author: ClockWorked Eve

comments.text:
When I experience Déjà vu I can almost always predict what will happen 
next. For example, I was at school one day and was working at my desk when 
I suddenly felt like I had done this before. This being Déjà vu. I looked 
up and with my brain, thinking that it had happened before, said "The 
principal will walk through that door in under 10 seconds roughly." Sure 
enough, he did. Another time this happened was when I was playing cricket 
and I looked away for a few seconds. I saw something like someone running 
and that somehow triggered Déjà vu. Yet again my brain said something like 
"Turn back to the game, the ball will be hit at you in a few seconds." And 
again, sure enough the ball was hit my way. Is this just a stronger case of 
Déjà vu? Or can I predict the very near future? I need to know its been 
bugging me.﻿
